AlgebraicExpressions.title: Algebraic Expressions
AlgebraicExpressions.description: Mastering expansion, simplification, and evaluation of algebraic expressions.
AlgebraicExpressions.content:
Algebraic Expressions Practice

Basic Expansion
Expand the following expressions:

1. 2(x + 3) =

2. 5(2y - 4) =

3. -3(a + 7) =

4. x(x + 5) =

5. 2y(3y - 1) =

6. -a(4 - a) =

7. 3(2b + c) =

8. 4x(2x - 3) =

9. -2(5 - 3k) =

10. p(p + q) =

Intermediate Expansion
Expand and simplify:

11. 3(x + 2) + 4(x - 1) =

12. 2(y - 3) - (y + 5) =

13. a(2a + 1) + a(a - 3) =

14. 4(2b - c) - 3(b + 2c) =

15. x(x + 4) + 2(x² - 3) =

16. 5(1 - 2k) + 3(k + 2) =

17. 2m(m - n) + m(3m + n) =

18. 3(2p + 1) - (p - 4) =

19. q(2q - r) - q(q + r) =

20. 4(3x - 2y) + 2(x + y) =

Advanced Expansion
Expand these more complex expressions:

21. (x + 2)(x + 3) =

22. (y - 4)(y + 1) =

23. (2a + 1)(3a - 2) =

24. (3 - b)(2 + b) =

25. (x + 5)² =

26. (2k - 3)² =

27. (m + n)(m - n) =

28. (2p + q)(3p - 2q) =

29. (x + 3)(x² - 2x + 1) =

30. (2a - 1)(3a² + a - 4) =

Factorization
Factorize these expressions:

31. 3x + 6 =

32. 4y - 8 =

33. a² + 5a =

34. 6b - 9b² =

35. 2x² + 4xy =

36. 12k + 15 =

37. m² - mn =

38. 8p² + 12pq =

39. 9 - 3x =

40. 5x²y - 10xy² =

Evaluation
Evaluate when x = 2, y = -1:

41. 3x + y =

42. x² - 2y =

43. 2(x + y) =

44. (x + 3)(y - 2) =

45. x² + xy + y² =

46. 3x²y =

47. (2x - y)(x + y) =

48. 4y - x³ =

49. (x + y)² =

50. 5 - xy =

Parts Of Speech.title: Parts of Speech: Verbs, Nouns, Pronouns
Parts Of Speech.description: Practice identifying verbs, nouns, and pronouns in sentences.
Parts Of Speech.content:
Identifying Parts of Speech

Basic Identification

Instructions: For each sentence, identify the specified parts of speech. Click on the words that match the requested part of speech.

Exercise 1: Spot the Verbs

The cat jumps over the lazy dog.

She sings beautifully in the choir.

We will travel to Europe next summer.

He has finished his homework already.

Exercise 2: Find the Nouns

The teacher gave the students an assignment.

Paris is the capital of France.

Happiness and success are important goals.

My brother bought a new bicycle yesterday.

Exercise 3: Identify Pronouns

She gave them the books they needed.

This is ours, not yours.

Who will help me with this project?

Everybody enjoyed themselves at the party.

Mixed Practice
Identify All Three

The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.

Practice Problems
Verb Identification (10 Questions)

1. The sun rises in the east.

2. They have completed the project.

3. Birds fly south for the winter.

Noun Identification (10 Questions)

1. The library has many interesting books.

2. London is a beautiful city.

3. Kindness and honesty are virtues.

Pronoun Identification (10 Questions)

1. She gave it to him yesterday.

2. This is mine, not yours.

3. Who told you about that?

Literature.description: Study of various literary forms and genres.

Creative Writing.description: Techniques for writing fiction and poetry.

Variables 1.title: Variables in Python (Set 1)
Variables 1.description: Introduction to variables, data types, and assignment.
Variables 1.content:
Understanding Variables

Basic Concepts

Instructions: Learn how to create and use variables in Python. Complete each activity by writing or selecting the correct code.

Exercise 1: Variable Assignment

1. What is the correct way to assign the number 10 to a variable called x?

2. Assign the word hello to a variable named greeting.

Exercise 2: Identifying Data Types

1. What is the data type of the variable age = 15?

2. What is the data type of name = "Alex"?

Exercise 3: Fix the Code

1. Find and correct the error in this line: 5 = score

Practice Problems
Fill in the Blanks (5 Questions)

1. = 25

2. = "Python is fun"

3. age =

4. name =

5. What will be the value of x after this code?
x = 3
x = x + 2
Answer:

Variables 2.title: Variables in Python (Set 2)
Variables 2.description: Practice with variable naming, operations, and type conversion.
Variables 2.content:
Working with Variables

Intermediate Concepts

Instructions: Practice variable naming conventions, operations, and type conversions in Python.

Exercise 1: Valid Variable Names

1. Which of these is NOT a valid variable name?



2. Correct this invalid variable name: first-name

Exercise 2: Variable Operations

1. Given x = 5 and y = 3, what is the value of z after z = x * y + 2?

2. What will result contain after:
a = "Hello"
b = "World"
result = a + " " + b

Exercise 3: Type Conversion

1. Convert the string "123" to an integer and store it in num:

2. Convert the float 3.14 to a string:

Practice Problems
Code Completion (5 Questions)

1. Swap these variables:
x = 10
y = 20
# Your code here
print(x, y) # Should output: 20 10

2. Calculate the average of three numbers:
a = 15
b = 25
c = 35
average =

3. Combine these into a sentence:
name = "Alice"
age = 30
sentence =

4. Convert boolean to string:
flag = True
str_flag =

5. Multiple assignment:
# Assign 10 to a, 20 to b, and 30 to c in one line

Strings 1.title: Python String Manipulation
Strings 1.description: Master string operations, formatting, and methods through practical exercises.
Strings 1.content:
Working with Strings

String Fundamentals

Instructions: Complete these exercises to practice string operations, methods, and formatting in Python.

Exercise 1: Basic String Operations

1. Create a string variable named greeting containing "Hello World"

2. What is the output of "Python"[1]?

3. Concatenate these strings:
first = "Data"
second = "Science"
combined =

Exercise 2: String Methods

1. Convert "hello world" to title case:

2. Count how many 'l's are in "Hello World":

3. Replace spaces with underscores in "This is a test":

Exercise 3: String Formatting

1. Use f-string to format:
name = "Alice"
age = 25
message =

2. Format 3.14159 to 2 decimal places:

String Challenges
Code Completion

1. Reverse the string "Python":
word = "Python"
reversed_word =

2. Check if "racecar" is a palindrome:
def is_palindrome(s):
return

Debugging

1. Fix this string literal:
message = 'It's a beautiful day'

2. Why does this fail?
"5" + 3

Real-world Tasks

1. Extract the domain from "user@example.com":
email = "user@example.com"
domain =

2. Create a multi-line string with triple quotes:

Strings.title: Intermediate String Operations
Strings.description: Practice essential string manipulation techniques for real-world applications.
Strings.content:
Practical String Handling

Core String Techniques

Instructions: Complete these exercises to strengthen your string manipulation skills.

Exercise 1: String Methods

1. Convert this string to snake_case:
"UserInputData" →

1. Format this with an f-string:

score = 95
print()

2. Display price with 2 decimal places:
price = 49.9
formatted =

Exercise 3: String Operations

1. Check if "sample.txt" ends with ".txt":

2. Split this into first and last name:
full_name = "John Smith"
first, last =

Practical Applications
Text Processing

1. Remove all spaces from " Python 3.10 ":

url = "https://www.example.com/page"

Data Cleaning

1. Normalize phone number format:

digits =

Lists 1.title: Python List Fundamentals
Lists 1.description: Learn basic list operations and manipulations
Lists 1.content:
Python List Exercises

List Basics

Instructions: Complete these exercises to practice working with Python lists.

Exercise 1: Creating Lists

1. Create a list named fruits containing "apple", "banana", and "cherry":

2. Make an empty list called numbers:

Exercise 2: Accessing Elements

Given: colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow']

1. Access the first element: colors[]

2. Get the last element: colors[]

Exercise 3: List Methods

Given: nums = [1, 2, 3]

1. Add number 4 to the end: nums.)

2. Remove the number 2: nums.)

Practice Problems
List Operations

1. Combine these lists:
list1 = [1, 2]
list2 = [3, 4]
combined =

2. Repeat list [0, 1] three times:
repeated = List Slicing

Given: letters = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']

1. Get elements from index 1 to 3: letters[]

2. Get every second element: letters[]

Lists 2.title: Python List Manipulations
Lists 2.description: Practice modifying and iterating over lists
Lists 2.content:
Python List Challenges

List Modifications

Instructions: Complete these exercises to enhance your list manipulation skills.

Exercise 1: Modifying Lists

Given: numbers = [2, 4, 6, 8]

1. Change the second element to 5: numbers[] =

2. Insert 10 at the beginning: numbers.

Exercise 2: Iterating Lists

Given: animals = ['lion', 'tiger', 'bear']

1. Write a loop to print each animal:

Exercise 3: List Comprehensions

Given: values = [1, 2, 3, 4]

1. Create a list with squares of each number:

Practice Problems
Sorting & Filtering

1. Sort this list: unsorted = [9, 3, 7, 1]

2. Filter out odd numbers:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
